newsitem.title: UK: Copper slips under $2,500 on LME pre-market.
newsitem.headline: Copper slips under $2,500 on LME pre-market.

text.p: Copper shuffled lower in early Friday trade, testing the psychological $2,500 per tonne area ahead of a long holiday weekend.
The market was fundamentally strong, but was susceptible to profit-taking and book squaring ahead of the three-day weekend in Britain and the U.S., traders said.
Three month copper jumped to a fresh one-year peak of $2,530 on Thursday morning, and speculative buying helped it close the afternoon kerb at a buoyant $2,526.
But prices slipped lower in late inter-office trade and on Friday morning were indicated at $2,495/98.
"There's some support around $2,495...whether it will be aggressively tested I'm not sure," one trader said.
Analysts said the market was over-extended, with the 14-day RSI at 80 at Thursday's kerb close. It was the highest RSI since last May when prices were climbing ahead of the Sumitomo scandal.
The market was still tight, with scant LME stocks in Europe, and inventories eroded by a further 1,325 tonnes on Friday to 137,675 tonnes.
Other analysts pegged support at $2,470/90 and then $2,462.
Not helping upside sentiment was news that supervisors at Chilean state copper firm Codelco's Chuquicamata pit are unlikely to strike, according to a source close to the talks.
Aluminium extended Thursday's decline, slipping to $1,625 from Thursday's kerb close of $1,633, despite an inventory decline of 2,575 tonnes.
"The mood is bearish and I would expect more lower numbers today. There's some light support at $1,616/17," a trader said.
Others noted that the convergence of the 30-day and 100-day moving averages at $1,620/21 should also provide a floor.
Zinc stocks showed another good fall at 2,350 tonnes, but the price still struggled to retain its upward momentum, edging down $3 to $1,361.

The market was solid, but would find difficulty making a great deal of upside progress ahead of the long weekend. Players were already long and the charts were looking overbought with the 14-day RSI at 73.5.
Resistance was pegged at Thursday's high of $1,370, then at $1,380, while support was seen at the 10-day moving average of $1,348, then at $1,340 and $1,332.
Lead gave up Thursday's gains, dropping $9 to $635.
The market showed two days of strength, but would have to consolidate at higher levels before the bear trend could be shaken off, analysts said.
"We would want to see a close above $650 or at least above range resistance at $644 before suggesting that prices would recover to target $700," said analyst Martin Squires of broker Rudolf Wolff.
Tin was barely moved at $5,760, down $10, and alloy was indicated at a little changed $1,493/98.
--Eric Onstad, London Newsroom +44 171 542-8065
